snippet.textDisplay: I seriously doubt there would of been a Latino police Detective in the 1930's, let alone on the LAPD! He'll they wouldn't even let no-whites fight in the earlier part of WW2. Jim Crow Laws didn't end until the the mid 60's.  Showtime! Please stop trying to Pander to us Black and Brown people, and just tell a good story. You can't rewrite history and at the same time, say people still face that kind of racism today! This feels like HBO's Watchmen all over again.

snippet.textDisplay: Reminds me of "Carnivàle" - which is a good thing (the show was so way ahead of its time) - and I love me some Natalie Dorner. Guessing that the trailer keeps some of the show's secrets and in the end it will also be a menagerie of different mythical and literary "heroes". Calling it "Penny Dreadful" is a little stupid, because the term is so inextricably linked with the UK and the 19th century... maybe Natalie Dormer is older than she looks in the series and made her way from London to the U.S. as an immigrant.
snippet.textOriginal: Reminds me of "Carnivàle" - which is a good thing (the show was so way ahead of its time) - and I love me some Natalie Dorner. snippet.textDisplay: My main concern here is that it appears that the show will depict Santa Muerte as an evil mythological supernatural being - when in fact she is a deity/saint that is currently worshiped by many many people, and is becoming much more well known now. Neither the saint or her devotes are evil, and I sincerely hope that Showtime has not made the mistake of taking a living religion and putting it into the realm of "folklore" while depicted a saint beloved by many as an evil demon.  The trailer seems to point in that direction with both imagery and wording, and that worries me. From the comments here it seems clear that people are mostly concerned with who is in it, and are totally unaware of the Santa Muerte issue.  I truly hope that this series is not going to bring awareness of Santa Muerte to people in a negative light, and that people who become curious about her will do research to learn.  There are many many books currently available about her, and documentaries and youtube series that people can watch.  The last thing we need is another TV show taking a real religion and using it to make a scary store out of.  I can't see how this isn't going to do that.  The whole basis of the concept of Penny Dreadful was that it was literally based on the Penny Dreadful literature of the Victorian era and imaginary creatures that authors made up for those and the types of horror novels that followed.  Vampires, Frankenstein, etc.  Let's not take people's real religions and use them for pretend stories to make money on TV shows.  This has the potential to negatively impact REAL PEOPLE.  Good people. Please do your homework.
snippet.textOriginal: My main concern here is that it appears that the show will depict Santa Muerte as an evil mythological supernatural being - when in fact she is a deity/saint that is currently worshiped by many many people, and is becoming much more well known now. Neither the saint or her devotes are evil, and I sincerely hope that Showtime has not made the mistake of taking a living religion and putting it into the realm of "folklore" while depicted a saint beloved by many as an evil demon.  The trailer seems to point in that direction with both imagery and wording, and that worries me. From the comments here it seems clear that people are mostly concerned with who is in it, and are totally unaware of the Santa Muerte issue.  I truly hope that this series is not going to bring awareness of Santa Muerte to people in a negative light, and that people who become curious about her will do research to learn.  There are many many books currently available about her, and documentaries and youtube series that people can watch.  The last thing we need is another TV show taking a real religion and using it to make a scary store out of.  I can't see how this isn't going to do that.  The whole basis of the concept of Penny Dreadful was that it was literally based on the Penny Dreadful literature of the Victorian era and imaginary creatures that authors made up for those and the types of horror novels that followed.  Vampires, Frankenstein, etc.  Let's not take people's real religions and use them for pretend stories to make money on TV shows.  This has the potential to negatively impact REAL PEOPLE.  Good people. Please do your homework.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ultimately, I’m excited to see the show continue—who would’ve thought we’d ever see this series come up again?? The creators of the show made something so incredible that I will give anything they put out there a chance. I think switching up the setting and actors isn’t a bad idea, I feel that if the show continued in the exact same story, it wouldn’t succeed after the first few episodes because the nostalgia of it would wear off, and audiences would want more.

However, I’m sharing the same concerns with some other commenters here, if the Mexican lore is brushed off and not the focus, I will be extremely disappointed. I’m unbelievably excited to see the exploration of Mexican lore, as it’s chock-full of figures and creatures that could beat the classic penny dreadful monsters ANY day when it comes to darkness and power. If they don’t take advantage of what this vastly rich culture has to offer, then they’ve forgotten what made the original show so good.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ultimately, I’m excited to see the show continue—who would’ve thought we’d ever see this series come up again?? The creators of the show made something so incredible that I will give anything they put out there a chance. I think switching up the setting and actors isn’t a bad idea, I feel that if the show continued in the exact same story, it wouldn’t succeed after the first few episodes because the nostalgia of it would wear off, and audiences would want more.

However, I’m sharing the same concerns with some other commenters here, if the Mexican lore is brushed off and not the focus, I will be extremely disappointed. I’m unbelievably excited to see the exploration of Mexican lore, as it’s chock-full of figures and creatures that could beat the classic penny dreadful monsters ANY day when it comes to darkness and power. If they don’t take advantage of what this vastly rich culture has to offer, then they’ve forgotten what made the original show so good.

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved "Penny Dreadful", one the best shows of the past few years. GOT and "Penny Dreadful" was my favourite Sunday night TV sandwich.
But this, I'm not sure about... Why is it even carrying the "Penny Dreadful" name?! For now only Natalie Dormer looks like the only one worth anything in this show. The rest should be "Penny Dreadful The Woke City" with a complete cast from Virtue Signalling Central...Of course don't forget to include a dose of racist white people picking on the downtrodden and oppressed minorities who are always noble, good and gentle...

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, so Penny Dreadful centered on works of literature during the 19th Century, with a strong emphasis on the Romantics and, of course, horror. I don't know how this show will incorporate such literary traditions, though they are using Mexican folklore (which should be interesting).


Perhaps, they also intend on taking us through the hard-boiled detective novels of the 1930s-40s which were seen as "pulp fiction" (though I believe penny dreadfuls could be classified as pulp fiction given the cheap pulp paper they were printed on? I'm not sure. Either way both were seen as "cheap" forms of entertainment).


The detective novel or story also has ties through one of the most well known horror writers of all time; Edgar Allen Poe. Poe with his story "Murders in the Rue Morgue," wrote what is considered the first modern detective story. Dupin is even seen as an inspiration for Sherlock Holmes. Murder and horror and mystery, now that's a winning combination especially when a bit of literary pizzazz and supernatural badassery comes in. Hopefully, this show doesn't screw up.


Though I will always miss Sir Malcolm, our young doctor and his son, the angel face demon with a penchant for portraits, the rugged Mr. Chandler, and of course the divine and utterly dazzling Miss Vanessa Ives.
snippet.textOriginal:
Okay, so Penny Dreadful centered on works of literature during the 19th Century,  with a strong emphasis on the Romantics and, of course, horror. I don't know how this show will incorporate such literary traditions, though they are using Mexican folklore (which should be interesting).


Perhaps, they also intend on taking us through the hard-boiled detective novels of the 1930s-40s which were seen as "pulp fiction" (though I believe penny dreadfuls could be classified as pulp fiction given the cheap pulp paper they were printed on? I'm not sure. Either way both were seen as "cheap" forms of entertainment). 


The detective novel or story also has ties through one of the most well known horror writers of all time; Edgar Allen Poe. Poe with his story "Murders in the Rue Morgue," wrote what is considered the first modern detective story. Dupin is even seen as an inspiration for Sherlock Holmes. Murder and horror and mystery, now that's a winning combination especially when a bit of literary pizzazz and supernatural badassery comes in. Hopefully, this show doesn't screw up. 


Though I will always miss Sir Malcolm, our young doctor and his son, the angel face demon with a penchant for portraits, the rugged Mr. Chandler, and of course the divine and utterly dazzling Miss Vanessa Ives.

snippet.textDisplay: Fun Fact: The Nazi's told Hollywood what they could and couldn't say about Nazi Germany prior to 1941. The result was that 90% of the United States was against entering the war in Europe. Sound familiar? It should. China does it now.
